(40/14401/4368)AMENDEMENTS AU PACTE.Note du Secretaire general:La lettre ci-dessous, du Gouvernement polonais, proposant un amendement a 1'article 6 du Pacte, est communiquee pour examen aux Membres de la Societe des Nations.republique polonaise mlnistere des affaires etrangeres-- varsovie, le 15 juillet 1921.N0 D. I. 2125.monsieur le secretaire general,D'ordre de mon Gouvernement et coriformement a 1'article 4, g 3 du reglement de 1'Assembles, j'ai 1'honneur de vous prier de bien vouloir inscrire a 1'ordre du jour de la deuxieme Assemblee de la Societe des Nations a Geneve, sur la liste des questions soumises a 1'Assemblee par les Membres cle la Societe, un projet d'amen-denient ad alinea 3 de 1'article 6 du Pacte de la Societe des Nations.Cet alinea est actuellement concu de la facon suivante : k Les Secretaires et le personnel du Secretariat sont nommes par le Secretaire general avec Tapprobation du Conseil n.Le Gouvernement polonais a 1'honneur de proposer la redaction suivante du dit article :k Les Secretaires et le personnel du Secretariat sont nommes par le Secretaire general avec l'approbation du Conseil. Pour ces nominations, il sera tenu compte necessairement de la competence et des aptitudes des candidats, dans leurs specia-lites respectives, et egalement, dans la mesure du possible, du caractere international du Secretariat et de la necessite d'y assurer une representation equivalente aux differents Membres de la Societe des NationsMoli/s.La premiere Assemblee de la Societe des.Nations a vote, le 17 decembre 1920, une resolution concernant le personnel du Secretariat, dans laquelle elle se prononce entre autres de la maniere suivante :a Dans la designation aux divers emplois on tiendra particulierement compte de la competence, tout en ne perdant pas de vue le caractere international de la Societe n (Journal officiel de la Societe des Nations. Supplement special, Janvier 1921, VII. Resolutions adoptees a la suite des rapports de la Commission n0 IV: Le personnel- du Secretariat, page 29, $ 3.)En proposant 1'amendement sus-enonce, le Gouvernement polonais s'en tient a 1'esprit de cette resolution de la premiere Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, (resolution dont il ne fait que preciser 1'importance et la portee juridique.)II le propose dans la profonde conviction que rien, en effet, n'est plus desirable et plus conforme a 1'esprit du Pacte que le rapprochement des nations et leur per-permanente et reelle cooperation a la Societe des Nations, ce qui ne saurait etre mieux atteint que par la composition d'un Secretariat 011 se concentreraient et se comple-teraient mutuellement, de la fagon la plus parfaite, les capacites techniques et les facult.es intellectuelles et morales des differents peuples.En faisant appel au plus ample concours de representants de differents Membres de la Societe des Nations, aux importants et multiples travaux du Secretariat, on obtiendrait la plus desirable application du principe de 1'egalite de tous ces Membres, lequel, conjointement avec le principe de la cooperation internationale, constitue la base fondamentale de la Societe des Nations.En meme temps, la confiance generale que le Secretariat a su acquerir a juste titre, par son labeur inlassable, ne saurait qu'etre renforcee encore et accrue, si on lui assure ainsi un caractere plus international.Veuillez, Monsieur le Secretaire general, agreer les assurances de ma haute consideration.Le Delegue -plenifotentiaire a la Societe' des Nations. (Signe) S ASKENAZY.L'Honorable Sir Eric Drummond,Secretaire general de la Societe des Nations, Geneve. S. d. N. D. 337. 500. S/2. Imp. Renaud(40/14401/4368)AMENDMENTS TO THE COVENANT.Note by the Secretary-General :The following letter from the Polish Government, proposing an amendment to Article 6 of the Covenant, is circulated for the consideration of the Members of the League.[Translation.^Polish Republic, Ministry foe Foreign affairs.---- Warsaw, July 15th, 1921.No. D.T; 2125.Sir,By order of my Government and in accordance with Article 4, paragraph 3, of the Rules of Procedure of the Assembfy, I have the honour to request you to be good enough to place on the Agenda of the Second Assembly of the League of Nations at Geneva among the questions to be submitted to that Assembly by the Members of the League, a draft amendment to paragraph 3 of Article 6 of the Covenant of the League.The present form of this paragraph is as follows : "The Secretaries and the staff of the Secretariat shall be appointed by the Secretary-General with the approval of the Council."The Polish Government has the honour, to propose that the Article be worded as follows : "The Secretaries and the staff of the Secretariat shall be appointed by the Secretary-General with the approval of the Council. The efficiency and qualifica-tions of the candidates in their respective branches shall necessarily be taken into consideration in making these appointments, and also, as far as possible, the inter-national character of the Secretariat, and the necessity of securing to the various Members of the League of Nations an equitable representation on the Secretariat."Reasons.The First Assembly of the League of Nations adopted, on December 17th, 1920, a resolution dealing with the staff of the Secretariat, which laid down, among others, the following principles : "That in filling the various.posts, whilst having special regard for efficiency, at the same time consideration be given to the international character of the League." (Official Journal of the League, Special Supplement, January, 1921, VII. Resolu-tions adopted on the Report of Committee No. IV. Staff of the Secretariat, page 29, paragraph 3.)In proposing the above-mentioned amendment, the Polish Government re-iterates the principle laid down in this resolution of the First Assembly of the League of Nations, a resolution the importance and legal scope of which it has only to mention. .The Polish Government submits the amendment in the profound conviction that nothing is more desirable and more in conformity with the spirit of the Cove-nant than a closer understanding between the nations, and than their permanent and real co-operation in the League. There can be no better way of obtaining this object than by forming a Secretariat where the technical abilities and the intel-lectual and moral powers of the various countries would be concentrated and would mutually supplement each other.By securing a greater co-operation by representation of the. various Members of the League of Nations in the important and many-sided work of the Secretariat, the principle of the equality of all the Members would be applied in the most satis-factory manner, together with the principle of international co-operation, which is the fundamental basis of the League..At the same time, the general confidence which, by its untiring efforts, the Secretariat has so deservedly acquired, could only be strengthened and increased if it were given a more international character.I have the honour, etc.,(Signed) J? ASKENAZY, Plenipotentiary Delegate to the League 0/ Nations.To the Honourable Sir Eric Drummond,Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva.
